results.title: Blowhard
results.creator_credit: Christopher Hinton, Brad Caslor, Michael Scott, Derek Mazur, Jerry Krepakevich, National Film Board of Canada and ACCESS
results.brief_description: An animated parable that deals with a familiar subject in an amusing way. We join in the business ventures of J.B. Edwards, an Easterner, who went West to create a fuel company called Consolidated Dragons. The company’s profits were sorely affected when the supply of dragons started to dry up. A solution had to be found - and was. Designed to encourage discussion of energy conservation. (Awards: Yorkton, Rio de Janeiro)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher Hinton, Brad Caslor, Michael Scott, Derek Mazur, Jerry Krepakevich, National Film Board of Canada and ACCESS

results.title: Blossom time: a romance in the music of Franz Schubert
results.creator_credit: Paul Stein and British International Pictures
results.brief_description: When Schubert (played by Richard Tauber) realizes his love for Vickie is not returned, he helps her overcome the obstacles of the court to find happiness with the man she does love. Throughout the film Tauber sings several of Schubert’s lieder. Music specially adapted and composed by G.H. Clutsam. Cast includes Jane Baxter, Carl Esmond, Athene Seyler, Paul Graetz, Charles Carson, Marguerite Allen.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Ramy & John
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Robi Watt and Sarah Wishart
results.brief_description:
12 x 2 minute minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
When Ramy, an Egyptian born inventor and engineer, needed someone to help him build a prototype paper making machine, he was put in touch with John, a ‘jack of all trades’ with a large farm shed in which all things were possible. And so their relationship was born. It gets stronger each day with a combination of true friendship and utmost professional admiration. The large shed, surrounded by beautiful native bushland in the Adelaide Hills, has many different projects underway: from old steam engines, dismembered motor bikes to pneumatically controlled guillotines and prototype lathes. We witness this teamwork, as Ramy and his older counterpart design, test and just generally find things to perfect in their shed, never losing their energy to find a solution. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blue Murder: Part 2
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Rod Allan, Southern Star Entertainment, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Based on the events that led to the Royal Commission on Police Corruption in New South Wales, ‘Blue Murder’ is a riveting and exceptionally well executed thriller about police corruption and gangland criminal activity in 1980s Australia.
Richard Roxburgh is outstanding as Roger Rogerson, the larrikin police chief who built a lucrative ‘alternative’ career based on bribery, drug money and murder. Tony Martin is Neddy Smith, one of Australia’s most notorious underworld thugs.
Rogerson and Smith’s activities are threatened when a young police officer, Michael Drury (Steve Bastoni), declines a bribe offered to him by Rogerson. From that moment on, ‘Blue Murder’ depicts how Drury’s involvement in acting as an informer on Rogerson’s activities led to increasingly desperate and murderous acts by both police and crims.
Acclaimed internationally as a landmark television mini-series, ‘Blue Murder’ was for years unable to be screened in NSW or available for view on video in Australia due to elements of the story being seen as prejudicial to legal trials in NSW and Federal Courts.
Cast also inlcudes Alex Dimitriades, Peter Phelps and John Hargreaves.
First broadcast (outside NSW) September 21st, 1995.

results.title: Bloodlock [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: A male dominated family try to break free from a crime syndicate. The bonds of blood are strong, as father and feuding son rally around Danny and his debt of $2,000, as everyone is drawn into the maelstrom, but at what cost? A tautly scripted piece about family and the inescapabilility of violence that pulls a punch as it winds to a frightening conclusion. Cast includes Amanda Crompton, Joel Edgerton and Simon Lyndon.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Bruno
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Sarah Wishart and Robi Watt
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Bruno has built a wooden oven in his shed. He fires the oven up early in the day, to bake the dough that he, his wife Guissepina, and his son Sam, have mixed up in a big wooden trough. By 9am the neighborhood smells of fresh bread as the beautiful rounded loaves are slid out of the oven on a long handled bread board before being eaten dipped in homemade olive oil and accompanied by other delicious flavors from the garden and of course, homemade wine. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Phu & Phong
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Robi Watt and Sarah Wishart
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Phu and Phuong’s shed is a serious mechanical jewel box. The exterior, a classic corrugated shed, gives no real impression of what can be found inside. The shed houses both of the brother’s prized possessions – their cars. The boys weekends and most evenings are spent in the shed polishing and cleaning the beloved, gleaming machinery, listening to music and generally just being with the cars. Phu’s low and sleek Nissan Turbo has everything that can open and shut – all digital of course, with every ‘after market’ improvement possible. Electric blue LEDs glow, exotic dials flicker, buttons and knobs are there for the pressing and tweaking: it’s a bit like having a low-flying spaceship in a suburban shed. For Phu and Phuong, the shed has been there for most of their lives. As kids they watched their father looking after his cars in the shed, which created their own interest in shed activities. Surrounded by their father’s ornate topiary, the shed dominates their small backyard. It was built to cram in four cars, which makes the morning departures something of a family joke. The brothers enjoy taking their cars out for a cruise on Sunday but the best part is then returning for hours in the shed to polish and love it some more. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blood sweat and tears. Vol. 1
results.creator_credit: Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this first volume of the “Blood sweat and tears” series contains the following episodes: “Obsession” looks at the seemingly obsessive attention given to sport by both the Australian media and the general public: investigates the questions why are there are sometimes when you can’t get anything on television except sport? and why do most people believe Donald Bradman is the most famous Australian of all time? “Winners and losers” shows the fine line that exists between success and failure in the ruthless world of international sport. “Black diamonds” looks at the issues surrounding Aboriginal achievements in sport. “Kill the bastards” looks at why people immerse themselves in a wider Self - a crowd of supporters, joined at the heart, not the head, bound by the team colours - to whom the one thing that gives life meaning is belonging, even if it means defeat.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Des
results.creator_credit: Sarah Wishart, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Robi Watt and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Des lives and works on his farming property in the historical German region of The Barossa Valley in South Australia. He has a hint of a German accent – all the more surprising since he is the third generation of his family born in Australia. There are many sheds on the property housing equipment that belonged to his father and grandfather before him. In a beautifully well-preserved hay thatched shed, a vast collection can be viewed as an almost historical “museum” to early farming technology. Des knows where everything is - although some of it has probably not been used for 20 or 30 years. But the equipment is still in working condition and we witness Des using a combination of that equipment as part of his working day. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sarah Wishart, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Robi Watt and Mark Thomson
